in may, teige gallagher was jailed for over years after a dcpcu investigation discovered that he had impersonated the nhs, sending texts which claimed details were required to determine when the recipient would be eligible for the covid-19 vaccination.

messages also play on the public's concerns in an attempt to make victims act hastily. over the past year, many criminals have exploited the covid-19 pandemic , sending out scam text messages about vaccinations and testing purporting to be from the nhs.
spot on! criminals will impersonate a wide range of trusted companies and organisations. for advice on how to protect yourself from messages, watch the video.

dogs and puppies were the most reported animal victims claimed they were trying to purchase, followed by cats and kittens. victims reported being scammed on social media, online marketplaces and specific pet-selling platforms.

in the /21 financial year, action fraud received over reports a month from victims of pet fraud. over a quarter of victims were aged to years old, and almost three quarters of victims were aged to years old.

more than million was lost by prospective pet owners in the /21 financial year, after they put down deposits for pets they saw advertised online an increase of over % compared to the previous financial year.

remember, if something sounds too good to be true, it probably is. if you think youve been a victim of an investment fraud, report it to action fraud online at or by calling .

so how can you protect yourself? be suspicious if you are contacted out the blue about an investment opportunity. dont be rushed into making an investment & take your time to do your research. seek independent & professional financial advice.

a fifth of victims this year were aged to years old which is unsurprising given the rise in cryptocurrency fraud. a staggering million has been lost to cryptocurrency fraud since the start of this year almost a third more than was lost throughout .

investment fraud is where criminals will present professional and credible looking online adverts, send emails, and create websites to advertise fake investment opportunities in commodities such as cryptocurrency, foreign exchange trading and bonds.

stalking is a pattern of fixated and obsessive behaviour which is repeated, persistent, intrusive and causes fear of violence or engenders alarm and distress in the victim. stalking can be perpetrated online or in-person.
the theme this year is highlighting the urgent need to stand together with young people to support them to recognise stalking and access specialist support.

were committed to protect those affected by stalking or harassment as we mark the start of national stalking awareness week.one in five women & one in men will experience stalking in their lifetime. it can lead to feelings of depression, anxiety & even post-traumatic stress.

we have seen a spike in the number of attacks on door staff at licenced venues.it is unacceptable and we will investigate these like any assault that happens in the city.we work closely with specially trained door staff to help reduce a crime and to keep people safe.

the slow walking protest was dealt with swiftly. protestors appeared on at am. officers were already on scene. at am, conditions were put in, and the road cleared. well continue to tackle serious disruption where it occurs.

were always on the lookout for signs that a road offence or another crime might have been committed. something didnt look right and then something didnt smell right. a drug wipe was conducted and driver tested positive for cannabis.
submitting false information to your insurance company to get a cheaper deal is never a good idea. this driver did that and therefore invalidated his insurance, and we seized the vehicle.

speeding is one of the five key dangers on our roads. we stopped a driver for travelling in excess of the speed limit. another problem was that he was disqualified from driving until october. driver reported and car impounded.

weve been catching more offenders on city roads. here are a few examples of our officers superb work. one driver thought he could avoid us near the tower of london. we stopped him & it became clear why he didnt want to stop. the car was not insured, so we seized the vehicle.

the investigation into fridays terrorist attack on is being led by the metropolitan polices counter terrorism command and continues apace. some areas of the are still affected. for more information please visit:
police statement: assistant commissioner neil basu gives a statement on incident
"work continues at pace to discover all circumstances surrounding the attack."

assistant commissioner alistair sutherland:"our ongoing work continues over the weekend and into next week, to provide important reassurance & visibility to the community, as well as playing a crucial role in supporting the investigation by the mps counter terrorism command."
to read the statement from commissioner dyson in full please visit:
"youll notice more officers on the streets in the square mile and across london, as we seek to reassure you that were doing everything in our power to keep london safe.
we continue to work closely with colleagues in the metropolitan police to return the city back to normal and we thank you for your patience over the coming days."

who courageously fought with the attacker and apprehended him. i am also proud to praise the professionalism and speed shown by the city of london police officers who arrived first at the scene and shot the suspect, without a thought for their own safety.

| met provides first update on strongest doubling down on standards for years

public trust in the met has been damaged. but there are thousands of officers determined to be part of the change. acting inspector keyur patel spoke to us about the challenges hes faced, and why becoming a police officer is an opportunity for change.

commissioner sir mark rowley on removing rogue officers:we've doubled the number of people leaving the organisation, suspending more people, taking on more caseswe're taking this on with a vigour that hasn't been seen for years
| the commissioner will be joining on at am to take questions from listeners. | listen live on the app or at

the investigation of new and legacy misconduct reports is putting significant demand on our professional standards teams. they're being bolstered by officers from other areas, such as serious crime and counter terrorism, who have volunteered to join the fight on standards.

an increase in resources in professional standards has seen: per cent increase in dismissals. per cent increase in completed investigations. double the number of suspensions for serious cases. twice as many cases considered at accelerated misconduct hearings.

the commissioner praised the honest majority of officers for stepping forward. calls to a dedicated internal hotline for raising concerns about integrity and behaviour more than doubled in the past six months. those reports are now being investigated.

the commissioner has written to the mayor and the home secretary to update on our work to restore confidence and remove rogue officers. it's "the strongest doubling down on standards in years". find out more about our progress at

| ground-breaking research into police deployment of facial recognition was published by the national physical laboratory today.read the full report

| independent scientific evidence finds that at the setting we've been using it, the performance is the same across race and gender.lfr enables us to be more focussed in our approach to tackle crime, including robbery and violence against women and girls.
| live facial recognition tech is a precise community crime fighting tool. led by intelligence, we place our effort where it is likely to have the greatest effect.

'our determination to change is real.''we don't deny the challenges. we can only rebuild consent with the public working with us to make the changes that makes absolutely clear we need to make.'- deputy commissioner ://

: a privilege to meet some of pc keith palmers family, colleagues &, alongside them & the speaker of both houses of parlia privilege to meet some of pc keith palmers family, colleagues &, alongside them & the speaker of both houses of parliament, to lay a wreath during a short private service. he gave his all - we will never forget
| you can watch the remainder of the session live, or catch up on a replay, at the link below:

| other key topics discussed include: renewing neighbourhood policing. rebuilding relationships with communities. tackling discrimination. setting our officers up to succeed. exploring oversight, scrutiny and new ways of working together to achieve progress.

| sir mark outlined progress being made to deliver higher standards including: investment in our professional standards teams. checking officers against national databases. reviewing previously completed cases. new legal route to dismiss officers who fail vetting.

| asked what he would do about those who would not change, sir mark said: im serious about this. the majority of our officers get this. they want to change. they really care. well take on those who dont."

| sir mark reflected on his confidence in the men and women of the met who do extraordinary work to take on criminals.if we can turn that passion, zeal and determination not just to fighting crime but to the problems in our own organisation, we can take on anything.

| he welcomed the support of assembly members for the work of the majority of dedicated hard-working officers. he spoke about his concerns that if the report was used to pillory and condemn that majority, then only criminals would benefit.

| sir mark appealed to the committee to recognise that the report must be a catalyst for reform and must galvanise policing, politicians, partners and londoners to come together if it is to be a positive force for change.

appearing at the police & crime committee, commissioner sir mark rowley repeated his determination to rebuild trust and deliver change.he renewed his apology to londoners and to officers in the met for the failings highlighted in baroness caseys report.|

we remember those who lost their lives in the westminster bridge attack six years ago.aysha frade, kurt cochran, leslie rhodes, andreea cristea and pc keith palmer who was protecting the houses of parliament that day.our thoughts remain with all those affected on that day.

'i'm doing everything that those cases illustrated we failed on in the past.'after baroness casey's damning report, sir mark rowley says he's working immediately to remove any officers that pose risk to the public.

dep commissioner for admits that she cant rule out there being more rapists & killers in the force:its dreadful, isnt it... i cannot sit here today and give you a % reassurance.clickto listen to her interview following the casey review.

"it's not just about individuals, it's about systemic failings"sir mark rowley, metropolitan police commissioner, tells that he accepts baroness casey's findings of racism, misogyny and homophobia in the force |

weve got more allegations coming forward - officers are increasingly confident to report things.that starts new investigations, which when proven, lead to officers leaving.we are testing a new legal process to remove officers who fail vetting.
'we are going to change. we are going to improve'met police commissioner sir mark rowley spoke to after a report found 'institutional racism, misogyny and homophobia' within the force

weve got fantastic men and women who are as up for the fight as i am - we want to do a better job for londoners.confidence has degraded over the last few years. policing by consent is not broken - but its damaged.we need to repair that and im absolutely certain we will do.

this report shows weve got hundreds of toxic individuals that need sorting out - were removing officers at a faster rate than ever before.ive been asking for new powers to be able to be more rapid and assertive in dealing with misconduct.im absolutely determined on this.

casey report | commissioner it redoubles my resolve to make a difference. the reason i remain optimistic, despite the ghastliness of this report, is that the evidence comes from my people they really care, they want it to be different.
| read the report, the commissioner's letter to baroness casey and explore the met's turnaround plan.

culture | unacceptable and deep-seated cultures have not been challenged.some of these are in specialist units, including firearms, where we expect the highest standards.we take these findings incredibly seriously and they will inform ongoing work to reform.

discrimination | found in our ranks, systems and misconduct processes.we know how deeply it impacts the confidence of the communities we serve.we are rooting out racists, misogynists and homophobes. we aspire to be anti-discrimination of every kind.

our people | officers and staff are struggling to manage demands put on them.we must change the reality faced by too many and set them up to succeed and build a strong foundation to deliver.we must get it right and we will.

"baroness casey's report sparks feelings of shame and anger - but it also increases our resolve.we have let people down, i am sorry."it must be a catalyst for police reform."- sir mark rowley, metropolitan police commissioner thread

we welcome baroness casey's report and call for it to be a catalyst for police reform.its findings about our culture and standards are very critical.they will shape our ambitious plans to reform and rebuild trust while delivering for londoners.

while the commissioner was on newsnight last night, we received ten calls relating to mental health crises. call handlers spent time to understand full circumstances behind the call which resulted in four officers deployed to emergency calls relating to poor mental health.
"we are not only letting vulnerable people down. there are consequences for policing too."we are looking at around per cent of police of our total demand being linked to mental health."
"we are filling a gap and we need others to move quickly so that these people get the right service from the right people," sir mark rowley said.

it should be emphasised that being involved in a case that forms part of the review is not in itself a finding of wrongdoing or sufficient reason to remove an officer from frontline duties. but where we find cause for concern, we will act without delay.

the reports being reviewed have all been finalised in the past and we expect the majority were dealt with properly. but we know weve missed opportunities and not been rigorous enough before so it is important we review the actions weve taken.

independent stakeholders from the violence against women and girls (vawg) sector will be invited to join an external reference group. they will bring invaluable insight and experience to this review process.

project onyx is part of our commitment to reform and deliver the highest level of professional standards. it is a safety net to review all officers and staff who have been reported to our professional standards directorate for domestic or sexual incidents over the last decade.

recent reporting may have given the impression there are to met officers actively under investigation for sexual misconduct.that is not the case.the work being reported on is a review of years of completed cases, not live investigations.

commissioner: there are cases where we should have been more assertive, throw officers out, and haven't.we'll turn those stones over and come to the right conclusions. we'll be ruthless about rooting out those who corrupt our integrity.you have my absolute assurance on that.

commissioner: we have not been tough enough at guarding our own integrity - havent dealt with issues with the ruthlessness and clarity that we deal with criminals. im putting in place ruthless systems to squeeze out those who shouldnt be with us.

commissioner rowley: ive been clear my top priority is restoring our integrity.to do that i need to take on officers who corrupt our integrity. our systems, policy & leadership need to be more assertive to put us in the healthy state we need to be.

carrick was arrested in oct and immediately suspended.investigation led by have published full information about carrick: his career history, public complaints and off duty matters and vetting changes

commissioner sir mark rowley: i apologise to all of david carrick's victims. we have failed. i'm sorry. he should not have been a police officer.i have promised action. integrity is our foundation - the met will become ruthless at rooting out those who corrupt it.

lovely to be invited to listen to the commissioner sir mark rowley talk about policing the future tonight. a fascinating insight into his reforms centred around trust, neighbourhood policing and using technology/data. genuinely innovative and interesting stuff
: for those interested some highlights from the commissioners speech in the thread below. for those interested some highlights from the commissioners speech in the thread below.

"i am excited about the future there will undoubtedly be challenges to come, threats will continue to change, that is what makes the met such a dynamic place to work."and we are up to the task. the met and our officers are at their best in the face of adversity."

policing hasnt transformed at the pace society has over the past years responsibility for that falls across police chiefs, regulators, policy makers, politicians, and others in the public sector. now is the time for reforms to set policing up for the next years.

"we will rebalance our policing effort to ensure resources are appropriately tasked to target offenders, locations and methodologies causing the greatest harm to londoners and their communities."making the most of new technology, we will get upstream of criminal networks.

community policing is the mets foundation we are a local police service.we will overhaul the current neighbourhood policing model becoming more visible, more engaged and more responsive to local crime and anti-social behaviour.

"i am determined to focus in on and tackle the blurred and bureaucratic distractions that get in the way of our core work. "we face supporting people with mental health, where the nhs is struggling. we are doing other agencies work to the detriment of police work."

commissioner sir mark rowley speaking : a different way of policing london is possible.this is built around the mission of more trust, less crime and high standards and delivering it through precise community crime fighting. full speech:

simon hammett, a retired inspector and fiona wilson, a retired sergeant, both received an mvo for their services to royalty protection.
commander ade adelekan, specialist operations, received an mvo for services to royalty protection, in particular his role in the platinum jubilee.
barbara gray qpm, assistant commissioner for professionalism, received an lvo for services to royalty protection, in particular her role in the platinum jubilee celebrations.

claire moxon, a retired detective superintendent, received the kpm for distinguished services to the mps. she revolutionised capabilities within the critical field of counter terrorism to ensure ongoing support for the immediate and long term disruption of terrorist activity.

detective inspector helene miller, from central specialist crime, received the kpm for distinguished services to the mps. she has made an outstanding contribution to countering modern slavery and human trafficking, improving knowledge and understanding on an international scale.

detective inspector nikki owen, from specialist crime, received a kpm for distinguished services to the mps. di owen is a long serving senior detective who has been integral to the success of numerous complex uk-based and internationally focused investigations over the years.

detective sergeant paul griffiths, from the counter terrorism command, received a kpm for distinguished services to the mps. he is a leading practitioner for witness interviewing and has dedicated his career to supporting witnesses and victims of major trauma and terrorism.

nicola baboneau, a community volunteer and community assessor, received a bem for services to the community in the london borough of hackney. nicola has worked tirelessly for the last fifteen years and excels in bringing faith, community and youth groups together.

pc richard fox, from the counter terrorism command and the met police choir, received a bem for services to policing and music. his dedication to the choir alongside performing his policing role has led to him revamping it in myriad ways, including recruitment and repertoire.

detective superintendent simon moring, from the central specialist crime command, received an mbe for services to health and wellbeing. he has made an enormous contribution towards supporting and improving the mental health of police officers and staff.

suzanne grimmer, a retired detective inspector, received an mbe for services to policing. as a counter fraud specialist, leading the cyber crime unit and protect, prepare & prevent team, she has designed and delivered innovative projects that have been adopted nationally.

phillip collins, a retired detective inspector, received an mbe for services to policing. as a national subject matter specialist in intelligence led integrity testing, his professionalism, passion and drive enabled the met to be at the forefront of anti-corruption policing.

detective inspector jonathan mearns, a counter terrorism (ct) liaison officer, received an obe for services to international ct policing. di mearns has been instrumental in liaising with multiple organisations in the field in the wake of major incidents overseas.

sir mark will also pursue other public agencies to ensure our officers can focus on crime fighting instead of their time being used to deal with the vast amount of mental health work in the community. read more in his interview with the times (paywall in place).

sir mark recognised the challenging role police do, saying officers injured on duty or suffering mental health problems as a result of work will be well supported and we are looking at improving further our wellbeing offer.

if we cant deploy % of our people (with this as high as % in some areas of local policing), we cant be properly effective. we are also improving how we put our people where our priority demand is and reduce internal bureaucracy.
reform to dismiss officers who dont uphold standards, under-perform, or no longer contribute effectively, will allow the met to become better at tackling crime.

we know our people feel stretched and under pressure were listening to them. plus we know we need to be better at reducing crime. we must take action and we are. with officers not fully deployable for reasons, including poor performance and misconduct, change is needed.

commissioner sir mark rowley has outlined how the met can support officers under pressure and reduce crime by better supporting those injured or ill back to full service and improving processes to challenge or remove those who are not performing to the required standards.

zara was a recent law graduate who had just started a new job at the royal courts of justice shortly before her death. her family have described her as a joy - a beloved human, child, niece, cousin, granddaughter and friend to all.

this is a sobering moment for the met. these steps are just the start of tackling these extremely serious issues - we will enable our honest majority to fight crime alongside communities, bringing more trust, less crime and high standards to the people of london.

public shocked that we do not have final say on dismissal: most hearings led by independent chairs.written to home secretary asking for urgent support with changes to police regulations so that the met has final say on whether an officer is fit to hold office of constable.

regulatory reform: lots for us to do within current framework, also grateful home secretary has agreed to look urgently at whether practical changes can swiftly and decisively root out those corrupting our integrity.

values & standards: officers + staff to understand exactly what is expected, how they must uphold professionalism, integrity, courage and compassion. clear direction in declaration of standards outlining expected behaviours - being up front about what is totally unacceptable.

change starts with our leaders: establishing a met leadership academy to bring rigour and discipline to how we lead the met. equip our frontline supervisors to bring out best in their teams. we will need expertise of others to fundamentally change our approach.

recruitment & training: immediate review of resilience and effectiveness of our recruiting, vetting, initial training and performance management of new recruits. vital we bring the right people in, who will uphold our integrity.

speed & assertiveness: we need to be quicker and more decisive to remove at earliest possible stage those who should not be in policing. we dismiss too few individuals in relation to misconduct. we will give leaders the resources to succeed.

tackling corruption & abuse: racism and misogyny just as damaging as corrupt relationships with organised crime. we will use the same tactics to defeat it: anti-corruption and abuse command will use proactive, covert investigations, intelligence and prevention.

commissioner sir mark rowley: i am appalled by the extent of the findings. integrity is the foundation of policing. we will urgently confront the culture, systems and leadership that have let down the public and our officers and staff. thread

baroness caseys interim report finds mets misconduct system is failing londoners and police.cases are taking too long to resolve; allegations are more likely to be dismissed than acted upon and there is racial disparity across the system. thread

commissioner sir mark rowley shares his reflections on the past ten days of extraordinary contribution from those in the met and forces across the uk in ensuring everyone could safely pay their respects to her majesty the queen.

in some small way i hope we will not forget this reminder of the shared values of police and those we serve.commissioner sir mark rowley thanks everyone who supported our biggest ever policing operation.read more here
officers and staff from the metropolitan police, along with our colleagues from across the uk, have paid their final respects to her majesty the queen while keeping the public informed and safe.
tonight at pm officers and staff took part in the national moment of reflection to mourn the passing of her majesty queen elizabeth ii.

a national moment of reflection will take place at pm tonight to mourn the passing of her majesty queen elizabeth ii and reflect on her life and legacy.the uk parliament will mark the one-minute silence and big ben will be struck.
policing offers incredible opportunities and proud moments where you can make a real difference. to all those involved in keeping the public safe as they honour her majesty the queen thank you.

the civil aviation authority have placed airspace restrictions across central london following the death of her majesty, until the evening of september. the restrictions apply to all drone flying. please do not fly a drone in london.

whether you are queuing to see her majesty the queen lying-in-state or youre heading into one of the parks to pay your respect, please remain vigilant. if you spot something suspicious, please report it to an officer or steward.
tonight at pm, officers and staff will be taking part in the national moment of reflection to mourn the passing of her majesty queen elizabeth ii.

the state funeral of her majesty the queen is the largest single policing event that the met police has ever undertaken. although this is a period of sadness, we are honoured and privileged to be a part of history.

we were honoured to host his majesty the king and his royal highness prince william at our special operations room today, where they met with officers involved with the complex security and policing operation.
his majesty the king charles iii visited our special operations room today to thank our officers who have been keeping visitors safe as they pay their respects to her majesty the queen.
raf police are working alongside the and royal military police colleagues to ensure the safety of those attending events to honour her majesty queen elizabeth ii in london.

our officers, as well as officers from across the country have been out and about in london protecting the public whilst they honour her majesty the queen. thank you to all those that have stopped by for a chat.
policing measures are in place to keep you safe but we need your support. if you spot something suspicious, please report it to an officer or a steward.

to serve under the extraordinary reign of her majesty the queen elizabeth ii has been an honour for our officers across london. her service and leadership will never be forgotten, and we're proud to play our part in supporting the public this week.
if youre out and about in london this weekend to honour her majesty the queen, please stay vigilant. if you spot something suspicious, please report it to our officers or a steward.

commissioner rowley: it's a reminder to me that with all the calls for reform in the metropolitan police - which are absolutely necessary - we should never forget that we've got thousands of dedicated men and women going out every day who are prepared to be brave for londoners.

injured officers updatecommissioner sir mark rowley has visited the two officers in hospital - they are in a stable condition. deputy commissioner dame lynne owens met with concerned colleagues at charing cross police station this afternoon.
further details in our statement

metropolitan police officers line the route and lead the procession for the lying-in-state of her majesty the queen.our officers demonstrated their expertise during these difficult times, continuing to support the public paying their respects.

our officers will be out and about in london this weekend keeping visitors safe as they queue to see her majesty the queen lying-in-state. if you spot something suspicious, please report it to them or a steward.

we accept that there is a lot of work to do in order to rebuild the trust people have in us, to show that we are changing and learning. we remain completely focused on building a police service londoners can be proud of (6/6).
over the next three months we will publish details about how we will act on these recommendations from hmicfrs (5/6).
there is clearly much more to do when it comes to tackling corruption in its widest sense. we are absolutely committed to this and work has already begun (4/6).
we have not given up on this case. there still remains a possibility of solving this murder. our work to make that happen will not stop no matter how much time passes (3/6).
this is another difficult day for the family of daniel morgan. we apologise to them again. no individual or family should ever be let down by policing in the way they have been (2/6).
we welcome hmicfrs report and realise there is a lot we need to improve on.

(2/2)we can only do what we do by working closely with our many colleagues from across the met and beyond, so if you're inspired by any of this, find out more about becoming an officer in the met -

(1/2) i hope this gave you an insight into the work of our expos and eod unit. we're lucky to have such incredibly skilled and dedicated officers and staff on the team. it's one of the many highly specialised capabilities and units that we have both in so15 and across the met
the unit deal with about calls or incidents a year across london that require our specialist response and expertise.
hi beth, all our expos are ex-military experts who are now in civilian police staff roles, but they are supported by police officers
the origins of expo unit in the met can be traced to . in response to the use of explosives by criminals to get into bank safes, we needed experts to ensure the safety of crime scenes.
we have two types of robots that we use - basically a small one and a big one, and it really can push a vehicle out the way! we use the robot whenever and wherever possible.
we deal with around incidents a year
anyone else see lana step over the top of a possible pressure mat? rest assured we would never do that.
all our expos are ex-military experts, but they are supported by police officers - called 'assistant expos' - who are specially trained in bomb disposal and cbrn and work directly with our expos

the met is unique in that we have the only police eod unit in the country and we provide a /7 immediate response to suspected chemical, biological, radiological or nuclear (cbrn) incidents as well as any suspected explosive devices across the whole of london.

evening, i'm matt and i'm head of the met's eod (explosive ordnance disposal) unit and senior expo.the eod unit sits within the counter terrorism command (so15) and we have a mix of civilian and police officers on the team.
| tonight our head of expo matt will be sharing his thoughts on .matts offering a rare, personal insight in to how this unique unit really operates.

sadly, sislin passed away earlier this year but her legacy will never be forgotten. she continues to inspire many others to follow in her footsteps to become police officers.
in she received a lifetime achievement award from the national black police association (nbpa).
sislin was working as a nurse when she decided to switch careers after seeing a recruitment advert for male and female officers.
sislin fay allen became the first black female police officer in the uk when she joined the met in .

incredibly powerful to be able to celebrate black history month . appreciating the impact that black, asian and mixed heritage officers and staff have had, are and will make to the history of policing. new scotland yard was the venue where we did just that!

ch supt peter gardner, said: i am deeply saddened to hear of the tragic loss of a childs life to knife crime in hillingdon. a family has been devastated and the effects of this terrible incident will reverberate throughout our communities.

we take hundreds of knives off the street every month and we've seized record amounts of criminal cash, locked up record numbers of drug dealers and we've been very successful on county lines, but we all need to do more.

we've got some fantastic schemes where we put someone - not a police officer - next to a young person who has been arrested to talk to them about whether now is a moment, a teachable moment they might be able to change their life.
we work closely with others to intervene early with children who are at risk. it's about trying to give young people other pathways divert them away from knife crime and violence.

"the responsibility for righting those wrongs, restoring our relationships with communities and supporting our black colleagues to succeed starts with those of us in positions of leadership but it continues through every rank and role in our organisation." /6

"we have let black communities down. they feel over policed and under protected. "we are still not sufficiently representative of london, black officers and staff still face discrimination and there are systemic biases in our policing tactics and support to victims." /6

"whilst progress has been made in the years since stephen's murder, we've not dug deep enough to confront the cultural and systemic failings that allow discrimination to propagate."this has compromised the trust of londoners and our ability to protect them from crime." /6

"on behalf of the met, i apologise again to the lawrence family for our past failings which will have made the grief of losing a loved one all the more difficult to endure."their dignified fight for justice continues to be a source of inspiration for us and so many." /6

today marks the th anniversary of the tragic death of stephen lawrence who was murdered in a racially motivated attack.in this short thread, commissioner sir mark rowley reflects on the met's response, the pace of change and the lasting impact on policing in london. /6

as with any major policing operation, we will reflect with colleagues and partner organisations and will take away any learning. we are proud of the efforts of our officers in helping to deliver a complex operation safely and securely.

officers worked proactively in a complex and time critical situation to identify those intending to carry out these unlawful and dangerous actions, to disrupt their plans and to make arrests as appropriate.

in the hours before the coronation, intelligence was developing rapidly that suggested plans to: - damage historic monuments on the route- throw paint onto or at the procession- lock-on blocking the route- use high volume sound devices to panic horses

hundreds of thousands of people came to central london to enjoy an historic day. we also welcomed a significant number of dignitaries from across the world who were kept safe by close protection officers - the largest protection operation ever undertaken.

more than officers worked alongside staff, cadets and volunteers, as well as officers from forces across the uk to keep the public and those on the procession safe and to ensure the event passed off without incident.

ac appeared at the committee earlier to discuss the policing of protest with a focus on the coronation.issues covered included the complexity of the operation, the application of new legislation & the wider approach to public order policing.

the uk, and london in particular, has a long history of policing protest.last year we policed more than events and protests in london. over half of these passed without any arrest being made.we do everything we can to respect the right to protest.

the was a historic moment of huge national significance.it was the most challenging, fast-moving and complex policing picture we have ever encountered for a national celebration.we are proud to have successfully ensured its safety and security.

this evening all six have had their bail cancelled and no further action will be taken.we regret that those six people arrested were unable to join the wider group of protesters in trafalgar square and elsewhere on the procession route.

we have now fully examined the items seized and reviewed the full circumstances of the arrest. those arrested stated the items would be used to secure their placards, and the investigation has been unable to prove intent to use them to lock on and disrupt the event.

it was not clear at the time that at least one of the group stopped had been engaging with police protest liaison team officers ahead of the event.the protest liaison team were not the arresting officers nor were they present in st martins lane at the time of the arrest.

taking into account the information they had, and the overall concern regarding security, people were arrested on suspicion of going equipped for locking on, contrary to section public order act . male was also arrested for possession of a knife/pointed article.
they searched the vehicle and, as well as a large number of placards, found items which at the time they had reasonable grounds to believe could be used as lock on devices.

taking into account the information that people were seeking to seriously disrupt the event, and the significance of the security operation, officers had been briefed to be extremely vigilant and proactive.

at am sat may officers working as part of the security operation in central london observed a group of people unloading items from a vehicle in st martins lane, westminster close to the restricted zone near the coronation procession route.

investigations have progressed - four charges have been brought so far. others more complex require time to progress.this evening six people that had been arrested and bailed have been informed they will face no further action.

it was not our intention to prevent protest. it is very clear a number of protests took place across the footprint both before, during and after the event with no police intervention. any suggestion all protest was prohibited is not correct.

ahead of the coronation, a significant police operation was launched after we received information protestors were determined to disrupt the coronation procession.our activity was targeted at those we believed were intent on taking this action.

update on arrests made during coronation arrests were made on saturday may. related to concerns people were going to disrupt the event, and arrests included to prevent a breach of the peace and conspiracy to cause a public nuisance.thread

it doesnt matter whether youre driving a ferrari or a reliant robin you need a front registration plate here in the uk. our officers educated the driver and a letter is in the post.

this bike was spotted doing well over the mph and our investigations found that the numberplate was folded up to avoid detection. this was due to the fact this vehicle had a warning for antisocial riding by another force. bike seized and rider reported.
we had to be the bearer of bad news to this driver. despite their partners word that they were insured to drive their car, we found that they were not. car seized and difficult conversation to come.

its been another busy week for our road policing units which included a costly lesson for a driver who ignored emails saying their policy was cancelled. six points, a fine and car seized which means further charges for the driver

its important to keep an eye on your belongings when out and about, especially in the summer months. it can be easy to think your belongings are safe under a table or chair, but a busy pub or bar is the perfect environment for thieves to go unnoticed.

antoines arrest was part of our proactive work in catching bag thieves in the square mile.dont come and try to steal bags in the city. our highly skilled police officers and cctv footage will result in you being caught and brought to justice.
christopher antoine, , of no fixed address, pleaded guilty at the old bailey to bag thefts over a -month period between june and march . the total loss to victims was around .
one of the city of londons most prolific bag thieves has been sentenced to an -month community order, hours of community service and a drug referral order.

applications for technology companies to participate in this years cyber innovation challenge close at pm tomorrow. dont miss the opportunity to engage with the financial services sector and gain :1 feedback on your products. find out more:

just stop oil protesters are slowly walking across tower bridge, blackfriars bridge, waterloo bridge and london bridge. officers are on the scene and will intervene if required to ensure minimal disruption to londoners.

we thought it would be useful to show what we do every day to support our unarmed colleagues and help keep the people of london safe. we know we use too many abbreviations, so we will explain them. bcu is basic command unit, the areas london is split into for policing. a thread.

were unlikely to intervene in civil disputes unless a crime has been committed or someone is in immediate danger. use our website for information and organisations who can help solve your issue.click here

retired pd billy sadly passed away yesterday. after serving years removing countless amounts of drugs, cash and firearms from the streets of london before he went on to enjoy years of happy retirement. thank you for your service, billy

welcoming local community groups, charities and businesses from london's black and ethnic minority communities to new scotland yard to celebrate their successes and achievements as part of the mets community outreach fund.

detectives recovered murder weapon from a pond and developed crucial evidence linking the suspect to the attack leading to dennis akpomedaye being convicted of murder.read more:

thanks to the fast-paced, detailed detective work the man responsible for 'ferocious' knife attack on anna jedrkowiak was arrested within hours and now faces years in prison.dci howie: "the individual belongs in prison where he cannot harm another woman"

are appealing for help in locating mawusi who is missing from area. he may be confused and wont know where he lives. wearing black shorts, green t shirt and a mauve overcoat. any information please call police on quoting /31may.

- a prolific burglar was arrested for being in possession of articles that could be used to enable further burglaries and an outstanding court warrant- a male was arrested for class a drug offences and breaching a community protection notice in whitechapelwell done all!

read below about how a wealth of evidence gathered by detectives has resulted in the conviction of two men for the death of subere badade in northolt.met police - more trust, less crime, high standards ://

the e6 area has been reported to us by local residents as having hotspots of anti-social behaviour.officers in the neighbourhood team patrolled the e6 area recently to deter asb and provide a strong presence.

we had such a fantastic time at the year alexander palace celebration event on saturday, thank you for everyone that came by to say hello. we was joined by tsg (territorial support group),dog unit and safer neighbourhood teams.

anti-knife crime workshop is driving students to come forward with vital information that is saving lives.pc graeme halleron is a school's officer in and uses his first-hand experience to educate students on the consequences of knife crime.
